 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.

violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

08/19/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION 1: The agency is not providing the necessary behavioral
health care to Youth A. Youth A has not received a mental health evaluation
recently and the agency has stopped her medications.
ALLEGATION 2: Youth A continues to AWOL. There is a concern of lack of
supervision.
INVESTIGATION:
The following documents were reviewed throughout the course of the
investigation:
 Emails
 Reporting Neglect and Abuse policy
 Mental Health Progress Note
 Medication Administration Review (4/1/21-6/30/21)
 Incident Reports
 Case note Report
 AWOL Policy
 Safety Plan
There is no video of the incident(s).
I interviewed Administrator 1 on 6/22/21 face to face at the facility. Administrator 1
reported Youth A has AWOLed multiple times and staff was always present when she
had run.
I interviewed Youth A on 6/22/21 face to face at the facility. Youth A reported she has
AWOLed multiple times but has returned. Youth A reported she was taking medication
for anxiety and depression. Youth A reported the medication wasn’t working. Youth A
reported she has “cheeked” her medications. Youth A reported the agency stopped
giving her medications for anxiety and depression for about a week and a half now.
Youth A reported she talked to a psychiatrist two months ago and talks to Therapist 1
once a week and sometimes twice a week. Youth A reported Therapist 1 told her she
would not be provided medications anymore.
I interviewed Therapist 1 via telephone on 7/22/21. Therapist 1 reported Youth A was
refusing her medications and cheeking them. Therapist 1 reported her medications were
cancelled by the Psychiatrist on June 7, 2021 due to her refusal to take medication and
3

cheeking of medication. Therapist 1 reported she had discussed cheeking of medication
in therapy sessions. Therapist 1 reported Youth A refused to see the psychiatrist as
well.
I reviewed the Progress Note completed by Psychiatrist 1. Psychiatrist 1 had a
scheduled meeting with Youth A on 6/10/21. Youth A refused to attend the meeting.
Hydroxyzine HCL 50mg and Intuniv ER 2mg were discontinued per Psychiatrist 1.
I reviewed the Medication Administration Reviews (MARS) from April 1-June 30, 2021.
There are boxes for each day of the week for code letters.
The following are the codes for the MARS sheets:
Staff initials=youth took medication
R=refusal
W=work day
F=Home with family
N=other explain in comments.
In April 2021, Youth A had eight empty boxes with no code letters in it. Youth A had one
“R” for refusal. There were thirty days in April. Youth A did not take Hydroxyzine
HCL 1 out of 30 days. Eight days were not accounted for.
In April 2021, Youth A had eight empty boxes with no code letters in it. Youth A had one
“R” for refusal. Youth A had two “N” for “other explain in comments”. There were no
comments on the back of the MARS paperwork. Youth A did not take the Intuniv ER
1 out of 30 days. Eight days were not accounted for and two days did not have
comments written for the code “N”.
In May 2021, Youth A had four empty boxes with no code letters in it. There were no
“R’s” for refusals or “N’s” to explain. There were no refusals of Hydroxyzine HCL in
May 2021.
In May 2021, Youth A Youth A had three empty boxes with no code letters in it. Youth A
had eleven refusals for Intuniv ER. Youth A had two “N”. Comments were written on the
back. Youth A refused Intuniv 11 out of 30 days.
In June 2021, both mediations were discontinued on 6/10/21.
For those ten days, Youth A had one “R” for refusal. Youth A refused
Hydroxyzine HCL 1 out of 10 days.
For those ten days, Youth A had eight “R’s” for refusals. Youth A refused
Intuniv ER 8 out of 10 days.
**Note: The empty boxes were not for medications that were described “as needed”
Incident Reports were reviewed for medication refusals. Some of the incident reports
and MARS codes did not align with the dates of medication refusals.
4

I reviewed nine Incident reports pertaining to AWOLS completed by Youth A. Staff were
supervising each time Youth A ran.
I interviewed Administrator 3. Administrator 3 reported staff were all aware of Youth A’s
triggers for running and her behaviors that occurred before running. Administrator 3
reported staff would position themselves by the exit doors and follow afterwards if able.
Administrator 3 reported the staff are aware of certain areas surrounding campus youth
would AWOL and they would check out these areas for Youth A.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The agency had enough staff supervising Youth A and were
aware of the AWOLS each time that she did AWOL. The agency
is an open program. All nine AWOLS showed the staff were
supervising and did react in a manner appropriate for the
AWOL.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
(c) Documentation of medical care and maintenance of
health records.
5

ANALYSIS:  Youth A was provided opportunities to attend therapy and
behavioral health assessments from a Psychiatrist. Youth
A was also prescribed medication for diagnosis. Youth A
refused her 6/10/21 behavioral health care. Medications
were discontinued at that time by the Psychiatrist
providing care to Youth A.
 MARS sheets identify an area of concern pertaining to
documentation. Documentation is not consistent with the
directions on the forms. Blank boxes are left without
dictation and code “N’s” are not described in a comment.
 Youth A refused Hydroxyzine ER 2 out of 70 days based
on the MARS.
 Youth A refused Intuniv ER 20 out of 70 days.
Routine medical services were provided to Youth A. Youth A did
not always utilize these services. Documentation of medical
care was not completed consistently. There were many blanks
left on the MARS leaving questions as to what happened to the
medications. According to the MARS Youth A refused
Hydroxyzine 2 out of 70 days. Youth A did refuse Intuniv ER 20
out of 70 days.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: The agency received information that Youth A
was allegedly raped by a male youth from the facility when they AWOLed
together and did not report this to Centralized intake or police.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviewed Youth A face to face at the facility on 6/22/21. Youth A reported a man
had inappropriately sexually touched her when she had gone AWOL. Youth A
reported she told this to Therapist 1.
I interviewed Therapist 1 via phone on 7/22/21. Therapist 1 reported Youth A stated
the male peer she AWOLed with around April 23, 202, forced her to have sex with
him. Therapist 1 reported Youth A initially stated they had consensual sex when she
returned from AWOLing but then recanted and stated it was not consensual.
Therapist 1 reported she had not reported that to Centralize Intake. Therapist 1
reported she thought it was the DHHS Workers responsibility to do this. Therapist 1
reported she did not call the police to report a potential crime and was not aware if
anyone had. Therapist 1 reported she was unaware if this allegation was called into
Centralized Intake, after she received the information. Therapist 1 does not recall
anyone coming to investigate the matter.
6

Case Note Report dated 4/29/21 documented Youth A’s conversation with the
Therapist concerning the AWOL and consensual sex with the male peer.
I interviewed Administrator 2, Clinical Service Manager. Administrator 1 reported it
was her understanding that the DHHS Worker told Therapist 1 the allegations;
therefore, they did not think that they were responsible to call it in. Administrator 2
was not aware if the allegations were called in.
Emails were reviewed from the DHHS Worker and agency on 5/24/21 with the
expectations that the DHHS worker would call the allegations into centralized intake.
Agency Mandated reporting policy was reviewed:
…When an Eagle Village employee has suspected that a youth or someone
associated with a youth has been physically or sexually abused or neglected, that
employee is to notify his/her supervisor immediately. In most cases this will be the
youth’s Family Therapist…Upon notification, the Therapist in charge of the case
shall: (2) Immediately notify the DHHS Child Protection Services-Centralized Intake
Division…
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
required.
The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure
compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL
722.621 to 722.638
ANAYLSIS Therapist 1 and Administrator 2 were provided information
concerning an alleged sexually assault towards Youth A. neither
employee contacted the DHHS Child Protective Services
Centralized Intake Division.
The agency policy denotes the “Therapist in charge of the case”
is to notify DHHS Child Protective Services Centralized Intake.
The therapist did not follow the facility policy of reporting the
information to centralized intake.
Additionally, Act 238, Sec 722.623 (1) (a) and (2) designates the
individual suspecting abuse and neglect to report the
information to Centralized Intake and then providing this
information to their superiors in the agency. This is not included
in the facility’s current policy. The policy must be revised to
reflect Act 238 Sec 722.623(1) (a) and (2).
CONCLUSION VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
